dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Welcome back to the podcast, everyone! Today, uh, we've got a really interesting piece to dissect. It's almost, like, a guide on what *not* to do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Welcome back to the podcast, everyone! Today, uh, we've got a really interesting piece to dissect. It's almost, like, a guide on what not to do.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I love those! Are we talking about, um, the classic pitfalls, or something a bit more... intentionally disastrous?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I love those! Are we talking about, um, the classic pitfalls, or something a bit more... intentionally disastrous?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely the latter! The article is actually titled "How to successfully sabotage your projects." [chuckles] It outlines six steps to basically guarantee failure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely the latter! The article is actually titled How to successfully sabotage your projects. It outlines six steps to basically guarantee failure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Here are six steps you can take to launch your projects effectively.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs] Okay, I'm intrigued. So, what's the first gem of wisdom for, uh, ensuring your project crumbles?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, I'm intrigued. So, what's the first gem of wisdom for, uh, ensuring your project crumbles?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the first one is: "Identify a starting point," but then it immediately says you should launch into action with a highly visible, public opening, even if your "troops are ready to retreat." Like, don't plan, just announce!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the first one is: Identify a starting point, but then it immediately says you should launch into action with a highly visible, public opening, even if your troops are ready to retreat. Like, don't plan, just announce!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Your troops are ready to charge forward, your stakeholders and investors are ready to support and your budget is safely in place. There is a final step and million-dollar question: How to start your project effectively?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, so, uh, ignoring all the prep work and just, boom, grand reveal? That sounds like a recipe for a very public, very awkward, retreat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so, uh, ignoring all the prep work and just, boom, grand reveal? That sounds like a recipe for a very public, very awkward, retreat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And then, instead of, you know, setting clear, flexible goals, it suggests managers should *avoid* working on objectives using the SMART formula – Specific, Measurable, Achievable...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And then, instead of, you know, setting clear, flexible goals, it suggests managers should avoid working on objectives using the S M A R T formula - Specific, Measurable, Achievable...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Managers work on objectives according to the SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable Relevant, & Time-bound) formula, usually long before launching a project.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Ah, the old "ignore SMART goals" trick! Because, obviously, our initial expectations and calculations are *always* perfectly accurate, right? No need for adjustments ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, the old ignore S M A R T goals trick! Because, obviously, our initial expectations and calculations are always perfectly accurate, right? No need for adjustments ever.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! Inflexibility is key. And speaking of useless tools, the article then mentions SWOT analysis—Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats—calling it "entirely useless."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! Inflexibility is key. And speaking of useless tools, the article then mentions S W O T analysis-Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats-calling it entirely useless.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The COVID19 pandemic has reconfirmed the value of an old-fashioned management tool: SWOT (Strength, Weaknesses, Opportunities and Threats) analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Useless?! But, like, how are you supposed to, uh, assess risks or plan for unexpected disruptions without knowing your internal landscape and external factors? That just seems wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Useless?! But, like, how are you supposed to, uh, assess risks or plan for unexpected disruptions without knowing your internal landscape and external factors? That just seems wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It says it's "not important to run a SWOT analysis at regular intervals." So, just do it once, maybe, and then forget it! Next up, communication. It suggests you should "disregard developing your communication strategy" especially in the post-COVID, hybrid world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It says it's not important to run a S W O T analysis at regular intervals. So, just do it once, maybe, and then forget it! Next up, communication. It suggests you should disregard developing your communication strategy especially in the post C O V I D, hybrid world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is important to run a SWOT analysis at regular intervals according to changes in the internal and external environment for your project... Therefore, I suggest that students should develop their communication strategy taking into consideration the most recent changes related to COVID-19...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. So, don't bother with, uh, new tools or training for virtual teams? Just assume everyone knows how to talk to each other across different platforms? That'll definitely foster misunderstanding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, wow. So, don't bother with, uh, new tools or training for virtual teams? Just assume everyone knows how to talk to each other across different platforms? That'll definitely foster misunderstanding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And then, for information management, it advises students and colleagues to "reject new ideas" and just focus on "keeping track of information and nothing else." No cybersecurity, no cloud issues, nothing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And then, for information management, it advises students and colleagues to reject new ideas and just focus on keeping track of information and nothing else. No cybersecurity, no cloud issues, nothing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effective information management is no longer just about keeping track of information, it is also about a whole set of issues that might impact your project, from identifying information needs, cyber security, to software and hardware crashes, problems of cloud storage and information distribution.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, ignore, like, the entire digital landscape we operate in? [chuckles] Just, uh, manage paper files, I guess? Because, you know, software never crashes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, ignore, like, the entire digital landscape we operate in? Just, uh, manage paper files, I guess? Because, you know, software never crashes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And the grand finale: for team motivation, you should "set up a whole set of values that can evolve into an *ineffective* organizational culture and diminish team spirit."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And the grand finale: for team motivation, you should set up a whole set of values that can evolve into an ineffective organizational culture and diminish team spirit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...it is important not only to motivate the team to work hard on the project and to develop financial stimulus, but also to set up a whole set of values that can evolve into an effective organizational culture and better team spirit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [gasps playfully] Oh, so, actively try to make your team *demotivated*? Forget common goals or shared values; just, uh, focus on making them unproductive. That's... [pauses for effect] next-level sabotage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, so, actively try to make your team demotivated? Forget common goals or shared values; just, uh, focus on making them unproductive. That's... next-level sabotage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. The whole article is a brilliant, satirical take on common project management pitfalls, framing them as deliberate acts of self-sabotage. It really makes you think about what *not* to do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. The whole article is a brilliant, satirical take on common project management pitfalls, framing them as deliberate acts of self-sabotage. It really makes you think about what not to do.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's like a reverse blueprint for success. So, if you hear anyone suggesting these things, you know exactly what they're *really* trying to achieve.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like a reverse blueprint for success. So, if you hear anyone suggesting these things, you know exactly what they're really trying to achieve.
